comments.body: why is this still needed? shouldn't this be in get_period_range_edges?

See the last paragraph of this comment. 
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23941#discussion_r237332194

Essentially, get_range_edges only accounts for the resultant labels, not the actual bins being aggregated. So the bins edges need to be shifted to reflect the base parameter.

I briefly thought about that. I *think* it'll only be useful for going from a DTI without and `freq` to a DTI with a freq. Changing from one freq to another doesn't really make sense for DTI or TDI.
@jbrockmendel thoughts here?
It isn't immediately obvious what DTI.asfreq means.  Is the motivation just to avoid the need for checks like this?
yes
Definitely skeptical of making a public method that is that ambiguous.  If this pattern is repeated a lot then a private method to this effect might be an easier sell.
Given that there's only 1 place in pandas, (and 2 in the tests), I'd prefer to leave this as is rather than define a new method.
yeah ok, just trying to avoid special cases.

This file has a set of mismatched signatures that's much more involved to bring into alignment that the ones we did in other PRs.

# `_upsample`
`DatetimeIndexResampler` and `Resampler` both define an `_upsample` method. The two signatures are only marginally different and could be harmonized easily. But `_GroupByMixin` defines an `_apply` method that is significantly different and then assigns that method to the class's `_upsample` variable (as well as `_downsample` and `_groupby_and_aggregate`).

# `_downsample`
`_downsample has similar relationships between `PeriodIndexResampler`, `DatetimeIndexResampler`, and `_GroupByMixin`.

# `_groupby_and_aggregate`
`_groupby_and_aggregate` has similar relationships between `Resampler` and `_GroupByMixin`.

Some parts of the `_apply` signature appear to be unused in this file. I'm investigating how much mucking around I can do with them. It might be possible to bring them all in alignment.
@gwrome there is lots of magic to make grouby/resample/rolling play nicely. But can of course do this another time.

so we already have count and size defined in groupby on the appropriate objects, see pandas/core/groupby/generic.py

but now we end up re-writing them here. Can you see if there is a way to combine these?

Yea agreed on this comment. This will add a third `count` implementation for classes that subclass `_GroupBy` (`SeriesGroupBy` and `DataFrameGroupBy` each have their own)

Do you see any way to consolidate?
I'm not sure there's much to share between this implementation and the other ones.
Hmm OK. Would definitely take this as a follow up to refactor - having three different implementations for objects deriving from the same base class is less than ideal
pls combine these; we don't need both paths; these are the same. if some tests need changing because the behavior changed, then pls do this.

The proposed change would work OK when `self._selected_obj.ndim == 1` but it does not work for other `self._selected_obj.ndim > 1`: this is because this function is expected to return an object with `ndim == 1`. I'd need a way to get the related type where `ndim==1`. Is there a blessed way to do that?
I used `self._selected_obj.__class__ when `ndim==1`and `Series` otherwise.

comments.body: this should also be self._selected_obj.__class__ (use a temporary variable here to avoid repeating)

OK for `count()`.

> pls combine these; we don't need both paths; these are the same. if some tests need
> changing because the behavior changed, then pls do this.

This comment is now displayed as revolved. Was it an error?

As for merging branches in `size()`, I don't think they can be significantly merged because:

* in the `ndim==1` we should return `self._selected_obj.__class_` and pass the name;
* in `ndim>1`, we should generate a type with `ndim==1` and we don't have a name to pass.

The only way to merge code between these paths would be to do something like:

```pyhon
@Appender(GroupBy.size.__doc__)
def size(self):
    result = self._downsample("size")
    if not len(self.ax):        
        from pandas import Series
        if self._selected_obj.ndim == 1:
            name = self._selected_obj.name
            klass = self._selected_obj.__class__
            kwargs = dict(name=name)
        else:
            klass = Series
            kwargs = {}
        result = klass([], index=result.index, dtype="int64", **kwargs)
    return result
```

Which kind of behavior change would you expect?

comments.body: is there a test for this?
Yes, here: https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/f2458dfaf5bdc22e22f58f7b720fa206b3cd88ef/pandas/tests/resample/test_datetime_index.py#L817
shouldn't this actually be close to where you set the origin (e.g. in the TimeGrouper)?

I don't have access to the variables `first` or `end` to infer the index timezone in `TimeGrouper.__init__` so I don't think I can do what you suggest. :confused: 

We used to infer the `index_tz` exactly on the same place before #31809 as you can see here on the tag `v.1.0.4`:
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/1ce1c3c1ef9894bf1ba79805f37514291f52a9da/pandas/core/resample.py#L1650

In my opinion that make sense since the API of `groupby` (shared with the `resample` API) can accept any kind of grouper, so the bins (that needs the information of `first` and `end`) can only be calculated when we apply the grouper against a Series or a DataFrame.

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

start, end = "2000-08-02 23:30:00+0500", "2000-12-02 00:30:00+0500"
rng = pd.date_range(start, end, freq="7min")
ts_1 = pd.Series(np.random.randn(len(rng)), index=rng)
ts_2 = pd.Series(np.random.randn(len(rng)), index=rng)

# => The example line that create this impossibility:
grouper = pd.Grouper(freq="D", origin="epoch") 
result_1 = ts_1.groupby(grouper).mean()
result_2 = ts_2.groupby(grouper).mean()
```
If reading the error message correctly can probably just delete this line instead of ignoring

This is in a mixin, so mypy thinks super() is object.

in use, if the class using the mixin is say DatetimeIndexResamplerGroupby, super() is Resampler where init has the signature is `    def __init__(self, obj, groupby=None, axis=0, kind=None, **kwargs):` and has a required parameter obj, hence the None here.

if we delete this line tests will fail.

```

============================================== 2 failed, 1670 passed, 10 skipped, 1 xfailed, 2 warnings in 548.51s (0:09:08) ===============================================
```
